messageBody:
Yes, I worked with both Fit and FitNesse for quite a while before
deciding to develop Concordion.

Fit and FitNesse are great, but they are typically used as scripting
tools. Concordion makes a different set of design choices to try and
make it easier to write specifications and harder to write scripts.

There are big advantages to writing specifications rather than
scripts:

- Longer lives. When you move to the next technology, you can reuse
the specifications since they are implementation-independent.

- Agility. Separating examples of required behaviour from the
mechanics of testing allows you to refactor the mechanics
(i.e. the implementation of your system) without affecting the
test cases.

Take a look at this page for an example of a FitNesse script compared
to a Concordion specification:

http://www.concordion.org/ScriptingMakeover.html

David
